Physics people with mechanics who are so used to seeing derivatives and gradients as their main protagonists may understand this instantly and intuitively. If del(f)=F and del(g)=G, where f and g are "-potential energy" functions and F and G are forces, the Lagrange multipler scenario means two forces F and G do no work and the potentials don't change! Therefore, both F and G (when they are non-zero vectors) are perpendicular to the path dr, hence F and G are parallel to each other, from which the Lagrange multipler method makes sense.  df=del(f)*dr (dot product: force x distance = work) =F*dr and dg=del(g)*dr=G*dr. For the constraint g=c, G*dr=0 always. For maximum f, F*dr=0, since no work to change the "-potential" f. Hence, F and G are parallel.

I think the constraint made the system have only 2 degrees of freedom. Cause if Det=0 then the matrix is not Linearly Independent. Therefore:  2x=λy, 2y=λx and xy=3 have only 2 L.I. equations. If Det=0. This means if λ is a real unknown and x is an unknown, and y is an unknown, the equations is unsolvable if you only have 2 L.I. equations.   3 unks with 2 L.I. equations, only becomes solvable when the constraint gave the system only 2 degrees of freedoms. Allowing you to solve for λ. This would also mean λ is not a real unknown.

@Arycke  Well, it's been 3 years. It is a hyperbola. It can't be an ellipse and a hyperbola both at once. It is a hyperbola. The ellipse is the sum. The locus of a point that moves such that its distance from a fixed point is equal to its distance from a fixed line is called a parabola. Now! By using those definitions, can you derive formulas for all three? That was the first question on my first calculus test. I took calculus all the way through up to and including the advanced level, and it was all combined with analytical geometry. I was a scholar of mathematics at Purdue University during the early 1980's.

because we don't care about the actual distance yet.. all we want to know is the location (x,y) where we can later find the minimum distance.. the trick is that the critical number will still be the same regardless if the square root is there or not.. so if that's true.. then let's just simplify the equation by getting rid of the square root :)
If we square a set of numbers, the smallest square will correlate to the smallest number in that set, for numbers 0 or greater of course

+John Lau   He means that when we are at a constrained min/max point, and we then move along the level g, the function should only keep increasing (if at a minimum) or keep decreasing (if at a maximum), but at the extremum itself the first order derivative of the function f will be zero (i.e. the function value will not change) in any direction the stays on the level g.

Well, that's the definition of critical point. If the rate of change wasn't zero, it'd mean the function would still change there. In extreme points, the function stops changind (increasing or decreasing), so the rate of change is 0.
I do not understand why at a constrained min/man, in any direction along level g=c the rate of change of f (gradient of f) must be zero? What am i missing?

Thanks for the comments. Here is what I thought. If both the objective f and the constraint function g are smooth, the constrained min/max must also occur at some critical points (if we extend its definition a little), as indicated by some directional 0 derivative. The question is how to define this directional derivative of f by incorporating the constraint g=c. If this could be done, then the second directional derivative could surely be used to test for min or max.

and a critical point is a point where first partial derivatives all equal zero. In this lecture Prof. Auroux talks about "critical points", but it is only to tell that these points can be minimum or maximum.
because to use the 2nd der. test you need a critical point. In the types of problems with constraints, min/max is not necessarily a critical point.
Usually, they are quite difficult.  They are somewhat designed, really, to be solved by a study group.

can you please tell me why we took lagrange multiplier in the pyramid?(at the end of lecture)..why gradiend of both func have to be parallel?
Watch previous videos. The gradient of f is zero whenever we let that equal to a constant: f(t) = k -> f'(t) = 0, because differentiating a constant with regards to anything results in zero.

You have to first realize that for an UNCONSTRAINED min/max, the directional derivatives in every direction at the min/max will be 0. You can think of a mountain with a flat top for example (top would imply maximum in this case).  So now think of a CONSTRAINED min/max. A constrained min/max is the minimum or maximum of a function with the caveat that there is a given set of points described by a constraint, described by g = c. Now why is the directional derivative in the direction tangent to g = c zero. Well imagine you look at the function f in 3d dimensions (f(x,y)), and then draw the level curve g = c under that. Now look at how the point on constrained min/max f in 3d dimensions and look at that same point on the translated down to the xy plane on g= c. You will see that because the min/max is only being compared to points on g = c, then on the function f in the direction tangent to g=c at the min/max that the curve is flat because all the other points on g = c are either lower than that max or greater than it. Basically you are observing a cross section of f that is in the shape of g = c and seeing that the constrained min/max will either be the highest or lowest point on that cross section, this making the slope at that point  in the direction of the cross section 0 .This also applies for higher dimensions as well, but just MUCH harder to visualize.

This is how I understand.  Imagine f(x,y) as a surface and g(x,y)=c as a curve on the xy plane.  Now, you can parameterize g(x,y)=c so that it becomes a trajectory expressed as g(x(t), y(t)) = c.  Similarly, parameterize f(x,y) so that it becomes f(x(t), y(t)).  Notice that f(x,y) is a surface, but f(x(t), y(t)) is a trajectory (curve) on the surface f.  Furthermore, the projection of f(x(t),y(t)) onto the xy plane is g(x(t), y(t))=c.  Since f(x(t),y(t)) is a function of a single variable t, we can say that at the constrained minimum or maximum, the rate of change of f is 0.
